awd_titl_txt: Conference: Workshop on Steroid Hormones and Brain Function
awd_abstract_narration:
The Workshop on Steroid Hormones and Brain Function is a conference dedicated to bringing together leading researchers from diverse scientific fields, such as neuroscience, endocrinology, immunology, and molecular biology to enhance collaborations and enrich our collective understanding of these complex systems. Steroid hormones are a class of chemical compounds that are naturally produced in all vertebrate animals that affect every cell type and physiological system from embryonic development through advanced age. The brain is the preeminent coordinator of these chemical signals to regulate everything from molecular processes within the cell to behavioral outcomes. As an example, brain-dependent elevation of the steroid hormone cortisol increases blood glucose levels to support the cellular energy needed to increase heart rate and muscle function when an individual needs to escape from immediate danger. The conference is strongly committed to inclusion and diversity in science and will encourage participation from scientists and trainees from all genders, ethnicities, cultural and socioeconomic backgrounds.

The conference originated in 1993 and has provided an important forum for established scientists and their trainees with the common goal to further understanding of the neuroendocrine processes regulating physiology and behavior. The limited attendance of approximately 100 researches facilitates deeper interactions among the participants compared to other scientific conferences. This year sessions will span topics that include the emerging fields of neuroimmune signaling, neural circuits, environmental influences on brain and behavior, hormone effects on the aging brain, genetics of sex differences, and Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal axis regulation and stress-related behaviors. The meeting will host a dedicated Young Investigator Symposium where talented early career researchers will showcase their work and receive valuable scientific input from established researchers. The meeting will also host a technical workshop with industry partners to highlight relevant state-of-the art technology, and a grantsmanship workshop for trainees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Workshop on Steroid Hormones and Brain Function took place March 6-10, 2022, in Breckenridge, CO. The topics discussed at this meeting included the latest research on how environmental toxicants affect reproduction, how neurons communicate with each other to decode hormonal information in the body, how the immune system interacts with the reproductive system, and how hormone changes with age impact mood and other brain-related disorders.

In the tradition of previous Workshop meetings, the meeting included a Young Investigator Symposium where a new crop of highly skilled and accomplished investigators presented their most current work. This NSF award was used to support their travel and other costs associated with attending the conference. Trainees were defined as persons that were post PhD and working in an established investigator's laboratory (i.e. "postdoctoral fellow") and/or those just starting their first independent laboratory. The meeting gave equal opportunities to trainees from all sexes/genders, diverse backgrounds, and all racial/ethnic groups to have a forum for their accomplishments. The small, close-knit nature of the Workshop provided an excellent environment for the development of professional networks and potential mentoring relationships for these trainees.

Since its inception in 1993, the Workshop has made developing and nurturing trainees and early career researchers a priority. The emphasis on career development is extremely apparent when examining the past and proposed Workshop events. Trainees are involved in a wide array of activities at the meetings including career development workshops, “Meet the Professor” lunches in which small groups of students spend individual time with a distinguished scientist, and a "Funding Workshop" that discusses funding opportunities for their research topics, trends in government and industry funding mechanisms, and grant writing skills. 

The conference also focused on initiating and promoting team science among interdisciplinary researchers. For example, several sessions integrated concepts from various biolgogical subfields to form a comprehensive understanding of factors that ultimately drive adult behavior patterns. The meeting provided time for extensive and constructive discussions in a small intimate environment which led to research collaborations using innovative approaches. The conference also provided an excellent opportunity for new investigators to have their work highlighted in a dedicated symposium, which provided training in scientific communication skills and a platform for them to receive valuable feedback on their work. We recognize that these trainees are the future innovators and drivers of scientific breakthroughs.
